text:
This report details exploration carried out on Yindi tenement E28/1318 during the reporting 
 period 8/01/2005 to 7/01/2006. Jackson Gold is the beneficial and/or registered holder of the 
 tenement. Tenement E28/1318 is located on the Pinjin Pastoral leases, approximately 114 km 
 northeast of Kalgoorlie. The tenement is located on the Kurnalpi 1:250 000 Sheet (SH 51-10) 
 and Pinjin 1:100 000 Sheets. The Yindi project lies in the Kurnalpi District of the North East 
 Coolgardie Mineral Field. Access to the project area is via the shire- maintained Kalgoorlie –

text:
In  December  2005  Barrick  Gold  of  Australia  Limited  (Barrick)  entered  into  an  agreement 
 (Argument Dam JV) with Jackson Gold Resources to acquire an interest of up to 75% in the 
 Yindi Project tenements including E28/1318. 
 Regionally the Yindi Project lies on the eastern margin of the Norseman- Wiluna belt within 
 the  Eastern  Goldfield  Province  of  the  Archaean  Yilgarn  Craton.  The  Yindi  tenements  are 
 located within the Yindi Domain which lies to the west of the Claypan Fault (Swager, C.P, 
 1994)  and  belong  to  the  Mulgabbie  Formation.    In  summary  the  Yindi  Domain  contains  a 
 west-  younging  sequence  of  basalt,  metasedimentary  rocks,  felsic  volcaniclastic  rocks  and 
 some  intermediate  rocks.  The  Yindi  Project  occupies  a  position  where  the  Keith  Kilkenny 
 Tectonic  Zone  and  the  southern  extension  of  the  Laverton  Tectonic  Zone  come  into  close 
 proximity  and  essentially  merge.  Both  these  zones  are  early  deep-seated  and  long  lived 
 fundamental crustal structural zones.  
 Exploration activities included a geological review and target generation. (Figure 2). 
 2

16.text: The physiography partly reflects the underlying geology. Greenstone areas are dominated by

17.text: low  rolling  hills  covered  by  open  acacia,  with  some  prominent  hills  near  Old  Pinjin

18.text: Homestead. Areas underlain by granitoid are generally flatter with lateritic plateaus and sandy

19.text: plains. The Lake Rebecca salt lake system, connected by areas of sand, silt and kopi dunes

20.text: occurs to the north of the project area.

22.text: There are no gold producing areas within or in the immediate vicinity of the Yindi Project.

24.text: Exploration activities included a geological review and target generation (Figure 2).

text:
The physiography partly reflects the underlying geology. Greenstone areas are dominated by 
 low  rolling  hills  covered  by  open  acacia,  with  some  prominent  hills  near  Old  Pinjin 
 Homestead. Areas underlain by granitoid are generally flatter with lateritic plateaus and sandy 
 plains. The Lake Rebecca salt lake system, connected by areas of sand, silt and kopi dunes 
 occurs to the north of the project area. 
 There are no gold producing areas within or in the immediate vicinity of the Yindi Project. 
 Exploration activities included a geological review and target generation (Figure 2). 
 3

43.text: Old Pinjin and east of Yindi Homestead. The basalts contain thin ultramafic layers/lenses and

44.text: are  overlain  by  felsic  volcanic  and  volcaniclastic  rocks.  Differentiation  trends  in  gabbro

47.text: Tectonic Zone. South of Yindi it appears that the basalt- gabbro sequence thins dramatically

48.text: and only sedimentary rocks with thin dolerite sills and local minor andesite are found.

text:
Details of the Yindi Tenement are presented in Table 2. below. 
 Table 2 : Tenement Details

 the  Eastern  Goldfield  Province  of  the  Archaean  Yilgarn  Craton.  The  Yindi  tenements  are 
 located within the Yindi Domain which lies to the west of the Claypan Fault (Swager, C.P, 
 1994)  and  belong  to  the  Mulgabbie  Formation.    In  summary  the  Yindi  Domain  contains  a 
 west-  younging  sequence  of  basalt,  metasedimentary  rocks,  felsic  volcaniclastic  rocks  and 
 some intermediate rocks (Figure 3). 
 The Yindi Domain is dominated by a major basalt sequence exposed in the hills around the 
 Old Pinjin and east of Yindi Homestead. The basalts contain thin ultramafic layers/lenses and 
 are  overlain  by  felsic  volcanic  and  volcaniclastic  rocks.  Differentiation  trends  in  gabbro 
 indicate  a  westward  younging  sequence,  forming  the  eastern  limbs  of  a  major  regional 
 syncline  –  the  Yilgangi  Syncline,  and  correspond  with  the  southern  extent  of  the  Kilkenny 
 Tectonic Zone. South of Yindi it appears that the basalt- gabbro sequence thins dramatically 
 and only sedimentary rocks with thin dolerite sills and local minor andesite are found.

50.text: The  Claypan  Fault  is  a  major  regional  shear  zone  which  separates  the  Yindi/  Mulgabbie

51.text: Domain and the Edjudina Domain to the east. It is a mylonitic zone developed in felsic schists

52.text: and granitoid sills and dykes to the north. The fault is characterised by subhorizonal to gently

53.text: north-plunging  mineral  lineations.  Numerous  quartz  veins  contain  considerable  tourmaline,

54.text: which  also  occurs  along  foliation  planes  in  the  felsic  schist.    The  Mulgabbie  Terrane  is

55.text: intruded by a series of internal alkali granites and syenites. Metamorphic grade is generally

text:
The  Claypan  Fault  is  a  major  regional  shear  zone  which  separates  the  Yindi/  Mulgabbie 
 Domain and the Edjudina Domain to the east. It is a mylonitic zone developed in felsic schists 
 and granitoid sills and dykes to the north. The fault is characterised by subhorizonal to gently 
 north-plunging  mineral  lineations.  Numerous  quartz  veins  contain  considerable  tourmaline, 
 which  also  occurs  along  foliation  planes  in  the  felsic  schist.    The  Mulgabbie  Terrane  is 
 intruded by a series of internal alkali granites and syenites. Metamorphic grade is generally

2.text: The Yindi tenements cover extensions of the felsic volcanic sequence that host the Khartoum

3.text: –  Old  Plough  Dam  gold  trend  and  the  Carosue  Dam  deposit,  and  the  mafic/  ultramafic

4.text: sequence that hosts the historical Mulgabbie gold mineralisation.

6.text: The main mineralised trend in the Carosue Dam Group of deposits extends for approximately

7.text: 20  strike  kilometres  and  consists  of  a  sequence  of  felsic  to  intermediate  volcanic,

8.text: volcanoclastic  and  epiclastic  rocks  with  minor  intrusives  which  strike  approximately

9.text: northwest  and  have  moderate  northeasterly  dips  (Langworthy,  1999).  The  three  resources,

text:
The Yindi tenements cover extensions of the felsic volcanic sequence that host the Khartoum 
 –  Old  Plough  Dam  gold  trend  and  the  Carosue  Dam  deposit,  and  the  mafic/  ultramafic 
 sequence that hosts the historical Mulgabbie gold mineralisation. 
 The main mineralised trend in the Carosue Dam Group of deposits extends for approximately 
 20  strike  kilometres  and  consists  of  a  sequence  of  felsic  to  intermediate  volcanic, 
 volcanoclastic  and  epiclastic  rocks  with  minor  intrusives  which  strike  approximately 
 northwest  and  have  moderate  northeasterly  dips  (Langworthy,  1999).  The  three  resources,

10.text: Karari, Whirling Dervish and Luvironza are concealed by 8 – 30 metres of transported cover,

11.text: comprising colluvium-alluvium and lacustrine clays and quartz sand. Beneath the transported

12.text: cover, variably stripped strongly gold-depleted saprolite occurs to vertical depths ranging from

13.text: 10 – 60 metres. Gold mineralisation is largely confined to the volcaniclastics and is associated

14.text: with  highly  visible  albite,  K-feldspar,  silica,  heamatite,  carbonate,  and  pyrite  alteration

15.text: assemblages.  Quartz  veining  is  largely  restricted  to  fine-scale  stockworks.  Mineralised

16.text: structures  have  two  distinct  orientations.  The  first  set  of  lobe  structures  strike  dominantly

17.text: parallel to stratigraphy and is associated with alteration dominated by silica-albite-pyrite. The

18.text: second  set  of  load  structures  are  characterised  by  flat  to  shallow  west  dipping  zones  of

19.text: tensional  quartz  veining  and  brecciation,  associated  with  strong  haematite-carbonate-pyrite

20.text: alteration. These observations are consistent whereby mineralisation occurs in steeply dipping

21.text: reverse ductile shear zones, with shallower-dipping, more tensional links between them.

23.text: Gold mineralisation at the Mulgabbie Mining Centre extends along strike, both to the north-

24.text: northwest  and  south  –  southeast  from  Mulgabbie  Hill.  Gold  is  localized  in  shear  zones  in

25.text: proximity  to  the  contact  of  mafic  and  ultramafic  volcanic  rocks  and  the  overlying  felsic

26.text: volcaniclastic sequence, which is intruded by acid porphyry.

28.text: Gold  mineralisation  at  the  Pinnacles  mine,  2.5  km  west  of  Hunt  Pinnacle,  is  related  to

29.text: ferruginized  quartz.  At  Son’s  of  Gwalia’s  Pinnacles  prospect,  RC  drilling  returned

30.text: intersections of 6m @ 14 g/t Au and 6m @ 12.4 g/t Au.

32.text: Troy  Resources  concluded  (Item  10355,  A43058)  that  the  favoured  rock  sequence  for

33.text: anomalous  gold  at  Yindi  consists  of  biotite-rich,  intermediate  volcanic  rocks  (dacite)  with

34.text: minor  associated  felsic  tuff  (probably  an  ash  deposit  occurring  is  several  thin  bands  within

35.text: dacite  flows).  The  secondary  sequence  of  importance  is  chlorite  schist  or  chloritised  basic

45.text: Project  area,  respectively.  Both  of  these  nickel  deposits  occur  within  thin  ultramafic

48.text: The Lake Rebecca Group comprises three deposits, namely Lake Rebecca, Rebecca South and

49.text: Rebecca  North.  These  deposits  are  owned  by  Heron  Resource  (90%)  and  Target  Mining

50.text: Corporation  Ltd  (10%).  An  inferred  Cobalt  resource  of  16.000  Mt  at  a  grade  of  0.05%  for

text:
Karari, Whirling Dervish and Luvironza are concealed by 8 – 30 metres of transported cover, 
 comprising colluvium-alluvium and lacustrine clays and quartz sand. Beneath the transported 
 cover, variably stripped strongly gold-depleted saprolite occurs to vertical depths ranging from 
 10 – 60 metres. Gold mineralisation is largely confined to the volcaniclastics and is associated 
 with  highly  visible  albite,  K-feldspar,  silica,  heamatite,  carbonate,  and  pyrite  alteration 
 assemblages.  Quartz  veining  is  largely  restricted  to  fine-scale  stockworks.  Mineralised 
 structures  have  two  distinct  orientations.  The  first  set  of  lobe  structures  strike  dominantly 
 parallel to stratigraphy and is associated with alteration dominated by silica-albite-pyrite. The 
 second  set  of  load  structures  are  characterised  by  flat  to  shallow  west  dipping  zones  of 
 tensional  quartz  veining  and  brecciation,  associated  with  strong  haematite-carbonate-pyrite 
 alteration. These observations are consistent whereby mineralisation occurs in steeply dipping 
 reverse ductile shear zones, with shallower-dipping, more tensional links between them.   
 Gold mineralisation at the Mulgabbie Mining Centre extends along strike, both to the north- 
 northwest  and  south  –  southeast  from  Mulgabbie  Hill.  Gold  is  localized  in  shear  zones  in 
 proximity  to  the  contact  of  mafic  and  ultramafic  volcanic  rocks  and  the  overlying  felsic 
 volcaniclastic sequence, which is intruded by acid porphyry. 
 Gold  mineralisation  at  the  Pinnacles  mine,  2.5  km  west  of  Hunt  Pinnacle,  is  related  to 
 ferruginized  quartz.  At  Son’s  of  Gwalia’s  Pinnacles  prospect,  RC  drilling  returned 
 intersections of 6m @ 14 g/t Au and 6m @ 12.4 g/t Au. 
 Troy  Resources  concluded  (Item  10355,  A43058)  that  the  favoured  rock  sequence  for 
 anomalous  gold  at  Yindi  consists  of  biotite-rich,  intermediate  volcanic  rocks  (dacite)  with 
 minor  associated  felsic  tuff  (probably  an  ash  deposit  occurring  is  several  thin  bands  within 
 dacite  flows).  The  secondary  sequence  of  importance  is  chlorite  schist  or  chloritised  basic 
 3.3 Nickel  Mineralisation 
 Although no primary nickel sulphide mineralisation has been located within the Yindi Project 
 area there are reports of trace Ni sulphides being recorded in the ultramafics west of Yindi 
 Homestead. The Lake Rebecca Group of nickel deposits and the Pinnacle Nickel deposit are 
 located approximately 25 km to the north-northwest and 12 km to the northwest of the Yindi 
 Project  area,  respectively.  Both  of  these  nickel  deposits  occur  within  thin  ultramafic 
 layers/lenses of the Mulgabbie Formation. 
 The Lake Rebecca Group comprises three deposits, namely Lake Rebecca, Rebecca South and 
 Rebecca  North.  These  deposits  are  owned  by  Heron  Resource  (90%)  and  Target  Mining 
 Corporation  Ltd  (10%).  An  inferred  Cobalt  resource  of  16.000  Mt  at  a  grade  of  0.05%  for 
 7

text:
The  current  owner  of  the  Pinnacles  Nickel  deposit  is  Peninsula  Minerals  Ltd.  An  inferred 
 resource of 50.000 Mt at 0.7% Ni for a contained mineral content of 0.350 Mt is published by 
 From the Landsat TM Image (Figure 4.) it can be seen that the dominant feature in the area is 
 the  Lake  Rebecca  salt  lake  system.  The  salt  lakes  and  claypans  have  been  described  by 
 Swager,  C.  P  (1994)  as  containing  interbedded  clay  and  sand  with  evaporite  minerals 
 (gypsum, halite) and are surrounded by stabilized dunes of sand, silt and gypsum which were 
 blown from the dried-out playas.  
 The project covers an area of poorly exposed and deeply weathered and leached greenstone  
 terrane,  often  with  extensive  surficial  cover.  In  the  few  areas  where  residual  material  is 
 preserved,  a  deep  and  intense  weathering  profile  occurs.  According  to  a  regolith  study  by 
 Metex the laterite is partially preserved over deep saprolite, with intensive leaching of gold 
 locally to the saprock/bedrock interface, especially in felsic rocks. Metex concluded that the 
 drilling  indicated  that  supergene  horizons  are  developed  towards  the  profile  base,  at 
 saprolite/saprock  contacts,  and  not  higher  in  the  profile  as  traditionally  developed  in  more 
 Extensive  colluvium  sand  plains  and  partially  lateritised  paleochannels  are  developed  away

40.text: The  dominant  structural  trend  within  the  Yindi  Project  area  as  evident  in  the  regional

41.text: aeromagnetic data is north-northwest in the southern portion and diverges north-west around

42.text: the Galvalley Monzogranite. The majority of these structures are layer parallel faults.

44.text: The sedimentary and felsic volcanic rocks are generally represented by the magnetically quite

45.text: areas, while the mafic and in particular the ultramafic units are present as magnetic highs.

47.text: Proterozoic dykes trending 075o are prominent in the aeromagnetics. One north-east trending

48.text: Proterzoic dyke cuts through the project area.

50.text: The regional aeromagnetic image with interpreted structure is presented in Figure 5.

text:
grains in a very fine-grained siliceous or chalcedonic matrix. 
 The  dominant  structural  trend  within  the  Yindi  Project  area  as  evident  in  the  regional 
 aeromagnetic data is north-northwest in the southern portion and diverges north-west around 
 the Galvalley Monzogranite. The majority of these structures are layer parallel faults.     
 The sedimentary and felsic volcanic rocks are generally represented by the magnetically quite 
 areas, while the mafic and in particular the ultramafic units are present as magnetic highs.  
 Proterozoic dykes trending 075o are prominent in the aeromagnetics. One north-east trending 
 Proterzoic dyke cuts through the project area. 
 The regional aeromagnetic image with interpreted structure is presented in Figure 5.

3.text: In the late 1960’s and early 1970’s the study area was explored for Cu – Ni mineralisation by

4.text: companies  including  Endeavour  Minerals,  Anglo  American  and  Carpentaria  Exploration

5.text: Company. Exploration for volcanogenic Cu-Zn mineralisation commenced in the early 1970’s,

text:
In the late 1960’s and early 1970’s the study area was explored for Cu – Ni mineralisation by 
 companies  including  Endeavour  Minerals,  Anglo  American  and  Carpentaria  Exploration 
 Company. Exploration for volcanogenic Cu-Zn mineralisation commenced in the early 1970’s,

13.text: values in the 1 to 2.8% range were obtained in lateritized ultramafic at 3m to 30m depths in

14.text: the vicinity of Gilgarna Rock by Western Mining Corporation Ltd in the early 1980’s (Item

15.text: 2158) on the west limb of the Yalgangi syncline.

17.text: The  northern  portion  of  tenement  E28/1318  falls  within  BHP  Minerals  Pty  Ltd’s  Eleanor

18.text: Glen Gold Project (Open File Item No. 3263). Exploration was conducted between 1985 and

19.text: 1987 for alluvial gold in Eocene fluvial pebbly sands overlain by Miocene/ Pliocene lacastrine

20.text: clays and fluvial sands, and recent salt lake sediments during the period 1985 to 1987. These

21.text: units  fill  paleochannels  cut  is  Archaean  granite/  greenstone  terrain.  No  significant  gold

22.text: anomalies were reported from drill sample assays.

24.text: The north eastern portion of Carbine Gold NL’s Yindi Gold Exploration Project (Open File

25.text: Item No. 5380 & 5714) covers the southern half of tenement E28/1318.  Exploration for gold

26.text: during the period 1986 to 1991 was conducted over a poorly exposed north-trending sequence

27.text: of  basic  and  felsic  volcanics  and  intrusives,  clastic  sediments,  banded  iron  formation  and

28.text: minor serpentinites which are largely obscured by Tertiary laterite and Quarternary sheetwash

29.text: and  alluvium.  A  major  shear  zone  with  minor  old  workings  transacted  Carbine  Gold’s

30.text: tenements.  BLEG  soil  sampling,  followed  up  by  -80  mesh  soil  sampling  outlined  two

31.text: apparently  strike-continuous  anomalous  zones  along  the  eastern  side  of  the  tenements  and

32.text: numerous  anomalous  spot  highs.  These  anomalies  fall  to  the  southeast  of  the  current  Yindi

33.text: Project and included the Hayman and Brompton anomalies, both of which are located along

34.text: the Claypan Shear System. At Hayman anomalous soils are associated with an insitu laterite

35.text: overlying  gabbro  or  deeply  weathered  mafic  volcanic  rocks.  There  are  no  known  gold

36.text: workings or showings. Soil anomalism at Brompton is associated with shearing that exhibits

37.text: strong biotite alteration within high magnesium basalt. Soil cover is thin and of a depositional

text:
values in the 1 to 2.8% range were obtained in lateritized ultramafic at 3m to 30m depths in 
 the vicinity of Gilgarna Rock by Western Mining Corporation Ltd in the early 1980’s (Item 
 2158) on the west limb of the Yalgangi syncline.   
 The  northern  portion  of  tenement  E28/1318  falls  within  BHP  Minerals  Pty  Ltd’s  Eleanor 
 Glen Gold Project (Open File Item No. 3263). Exploration was conducted between 1985 and 
 1987 for alluvial gold in Eocene fluvial pebbly sands overlain by Miocene/ Pliocene lacastrine 
 clays and fluvial sands, and recent salt lake sediments during the period 1985 to 1987. These 
 units  fill  paleochannels  cut  is  Archaean  granite/  greenstone  terrain.  No  significant  gold 
 anomalies were reported from drill sample assays. 
 The north eastern portion of Carbine Gold NL’s Yindi Gold Exploration Project (Open File 
 Item No. 5380 & 5714) covers the southern half of tenement E28/1318.  Exploration for gold 
 during the period 1986 to 1991 was conducted over a poorly exposed north-trending sequence 
 of  basic  and  felsic  volcanics  and  intrusives,  clastic  sediments,  banded  iron  formation  and 
 minor serpentinites which are largely obscured by Tertiary laterite and Quarternary sheetwash 
 and  alluvium.  A  major  shear  zone  with  minor  old  workings  transacted  Carbine  Gold’s 
 tenements.  BLEG  soil  sampling,  followed  up  by  -80  mesh  soil  sampling  outlined  two 
 apparently  strike-continuous  anomalous  zones  along  the  eastern  side  of  the  tenements  and 
 numerous  anomalous  spot  highs.  These  anomalies  fall  to  the  southeast  of  the  current  Yindi 
 Project and included the Hayman and Brompton anomalies, both of which are located along 
 the Claypan Shear System. At Hayman anomalous soils are associated with an insitu laterite 
 overlying  gabbro  or  deeply  weathered  mafic  volcanic  rocks.  There  are  no  known  gold 
 workings or showings. Soil anomalism at Brompton is associated with shearing that exhibits 
 strong biotite alteration within high magnesium basalt. Soil cover is thin and of a depositional 
 nature.  RAB  drilling  found  several  of  the  anomalies  to  be  shallow  surface  enrichments 
 associated  with  the  laterite  profile.  Four  significant  bedrock  anomalies  were  found.  In  late 
 1989 operatorship of this project changed from Carbine Gold NL to Placer Exploration Ltd. 
 BLEG stream sediment and soil samples were collected and regolith mapping was conducted. 
 Almost without exception the elevated geochemical responses were interpreted to be related to 
 regolith  units.  Three  areas,  which  do  not  fall  into  the  current  Yindi  Project  area  where 
 recommended  for  further  exploration.  In  1993  Yardarino  Mining  NL  (80%)  and  Croesus 
 Mining NL (20%) took over Placer Exploration’s Yindi Project. In February 1994 the project 
 was farmed out to Anglo Australian Resources and Troy Resources NL whom subsequently 
 withdrew  in  1995  and  1996  respectively.  Yardarino  Mining  NL  resumed  tenement  and 
 exploration management. Several phases of vacuum drilling, as well follow-up RAB and RC 
 drilling where conducted by Yardarino Mining and Troy Resources. Yardarino concluded that 
 anomalous  gold  in  soils  is  widespread  in  the Yindi Project with numerous anomalies being

9.text: Raeside to explore Tertiary channels for redox related uranium mineralisation as well as gold.

5.0. Exploration Activities

23.text: A geological review of the Yindi Project has resulted in the following areas being  identified

24.text: as potential targets for gold mineralisation (Figures 6 & 7).

28.text: The  Galvalley  Monzogranite  is  a  major  ovoid  pluton  which  underlies  the  northern  Yindi

29.text: Project. The central Yindi tenements are located within the pressure shadow of the Galvalley

30.text: Monzogranite, which has been identified by Brett Davis of RSG as being of interest during a

31.text: regional study (Figure 6.). This area has been identified as a strong strain domain and as being

32.text: of  interest  due  to  the  granite  contact  being  at  low  angle  to  the  syn-mineralisation  principle

33.text: stress.  From  geological  mapping  of  the  region  there appears to be a small granite  intrusion

34.text: within the pressure shadow area. Very limited surface sampling and no drilling has been found

35.text: in the open file data over this tenement. The location of the tenement over Lake Rebecca could

36.text: provide an explanation for the lack of previous exploration in this area.

40.text: The Yindi Thrust area was identified during a regional structural study undertaken by Brett

41.text: Davis  as  being  a  target  area  within  the  Yindi  Project  (Figure  6  &  7).  The  area  has  been

42.text: described as a region of ‘high strain’ with dextral movement. This area also occurs directly

43.text: along  strike  of  the  mineralisation  at  the  Mulgabbie  Mining  Centre.  There  has  been  some

44.text: surface  geochemical  sampling,  although  not  systematically  targeting  the  Yindi  Thrust  area.

text:
5.1 Target Generation 
 A geological review of the Yindi Project has resulted in the following areas being  identified 
 as potential targets for gold mineralisation (Figures 6 & 7). 
 5.1.1 Galvalley Monzogranite Pressure Shadow 
 The  Galvalley  Monzogranite  is  a  major  ovoid  pluton  which  underlies  the  northern  Yindi 
 Project. The central Yindi tenements are located within the pressure shadow of the Galvalley 
 Monzogranite, which has been identified by Brett Davis of RSG as being of interest during a 
 regional study (Figure 6.). This area has been identified as a strong strain domain and as being 
 of  interest  due  to  the  granite  contact  being  at  low  angle  to  the  syn-mineralisation  principle 
 stress.  From  geological  mapping  of  the  region  there appears to be a small granite  intrusion 
 within the pressure shadow area. Very limited surface sampling and no drilling has been found 
 in the open file data over this tenement. The location of the tenement over Lake Rebecca could 
 provide an explanation for the lack of previous exploration in this area. 
 5.1.2 Yindi Trust Area 
 The Yindi Thrust area was identified during a regional structural study undertaken by Brett 
 Davis  as  being  a  target  area  within  the  Yindi  Project  (Figure  6  &  7).  The  area  has  been 
 described as a region of ‘high strain’ with dextral movement. This area also occurs directly 
 along  strike  of  the  mineralisation  at  the  Mulgabbie  Mining  Centre.  There  has  been  some 
 surface  geochemical  sampling,  although  not  systematically  targeting  the  Yindi  Thrust  area. 
 Some geochemical anomalies were generated, which appear to become more coherent in the

text:
4.2 Previous Exploration – Jackson Gold Ltd 
 In  November  2004  an  aircore  drilling  program  comprising  10  holes  (YNAC001  –  010)  for 
 545m  was  conducted  by  Jackson  Gold  along  a  single  traverse  on  tenement  E28/1318.  The 
 drilling targeted a legacy NNW- SSE trending soil geochemistry anomaly in lithologies along 
 strike  from  the  historical  Mulgabbie  Mining  Centre,  which  was  identified  in  the  north-east 
 portion of tenement E28/1318. A weakly anomalous zone was identified in the drilling, with 
 the following significant intercepts: - 
 YNAC005 - 2m @ 0.64g/t Au from 50m 
 YNAC006 – 4m @ 0.16g/t Au from 28m 
 YNAC007 – 1m @ 0.13g/t Au from 67m

2.text: In the eastern portion of the Yindi Project an area of intense granite strain has been identified

3.text: during an investigation of strain domains in a regional structural survey by Brett Davis (Figure

4.text: 6). This region of intense strain overlies the southern half of a un-named pluton at Claypan

5.text: Dam which was emplaced as a southward- tapering, tear shaped pluton along, and just to the

6.text: west  of  the  Claypan  Fault.  This  pluton  has  the  same  composition  as  the  Galvalley

7.text: Monzogranite  (k-feldspar  megacrystic  monzogranite)  although  it  is  much  smaller.  There  is

8.text: some historical surface geochemistry but it was not specifically targeting this area of intense

text:
In the eastern portion of the Yindi Project an area of intense granite strain has been identified 
 during an investigation of strain domains in a regional structural survey by Brett Davis (Figure 
 6). This region of intense strain overlies the southern half of a un-named pluton at Claypan 
 Dam which was emplaced as a southward- tapering, tear shaped pluton along, and just to the 
 west  of  the  Claypan  Fault.  This  pluton  has  the  same  composition  as  the  Galvalley 
 Monzogranite  (k-feldspar  megacrystic  monzogranite)  although  it  is  much  smaller.  There  is 
 some historical surface geochemistry but it was not specifically targeting this area of intense

9.text: strain. No previous drilling has been conducted in this area.

13.text: A weak surface geochemical anomaly is present in the southern portion of the Yindi project.

14.text: The anomaly appears to be co-incident with a north-west trending Proterzoic dyke and an area

15.text: that has been mapped as a region of high strain within greenstones (Figure 7.). This high strain

16.text: area is located to the south of a small ovoid granite intrusion. Sampling by Troy Resources

17.text: returned several +20 ppb Au samples along two traverses at a 400m spacing.

text:
strain. No previous drilling has been conducted in this area. 
 5.1.4 South Yindi – High Strain Area 
 A weak surface geochemical anomaly is present in the southern portion of the Yindi project. 
 The anomaly appears to be co-incident with a north-west trending Proterzoic dyke and an area 
 that has been mapped as a region of high strain within greenstones (Figure 7.). This high strain 
 area is located to the south of a small ovoid granite intrusion. Sampling by Troy Resources 
 returned several +20 ppb Au samples along two traverses at a 400m spacing.

3.text: During the 2005 - 2006 reporting period Jackson Gold continued to monitor and regulate the

4.text: environmental impact of its exploration activities.  This was achieved through the continual

5.text: use  of  our  internal  compliance  audit  program.    All  activities  were  undertaken  with  those

6.text: guidelines  set  by  the  Department  of  Industry  and  Resources  as  a  minimum.    Through  its

7.text: Environmental  Policy,  Jackson  Gold  is  committed  to  managing  its  activities  in  an

8.text: environmentally responsible manner and actively pursues environmental excellence.

text:
During the 2005 - 2006 reporting period Jackson Gold continued to monitor and regulate the 
 environmental impact of its exploration activities.  This was achieved through the continual 
 use  of  our  internal  compliance  audit  program.    All  activities  were  undertaken  with  those 
 guidelines  set  by  the  Department  of  Industry  and  Resources  as  a  minimum.    Through  its 
 Environmental  Policy,  Jackson  Gold  is  committed  to  managing  its  activities  in  an 
 environmentally responsible manner and actively pursues environmental excellence.
